examples.text: a table, two chairs and a desk
I cooked lunch. And I made a cake. *(= you are emphasizing how much you have done)*
She came in and took her coat off.

definitions.definition: used before a verb instead of to, to show purpose
definitions.sensetop: go, come, try, stay, etc. and

examples.text: Go and get me a pen please.
I'll come and see you soon.
We stopped and bought some bread.

definitions.definition: used to introduce a comment or a question

examples.text: ‘We talked for hours.’ ‘And what did you decide?’
Miss another class and you'll fail.

definitions.definition: used between repeated words to show that something is repeated or continuing

examples.text: He tried and tried but without success.
The pain got worse and worse.

definitions.definition: used between repeated words to show that there are important differences between things or people of the same kind

examples.text: I like city life but there are cities and cities.

wordOrigin: Old English and, ond, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch en and German und.
